### **III. LESSON OVERVIEW:**

$\qquad$ $\qquad$ This module by assessing your knowledge of the different mathematics concepts previously $\qquad$ studied and your skills in performing mathematical operations. These knowledge and skills will help $\qquad$ you understand solving quadratic equations using the quadratic formula. As you go through this $\qquad$ lesson, think of this important question: ‚ÄúHow does finding solutions of quadratic equations facilitate $\qquad$ solving real-life problems and making decisions?‚Äù To find the answer, perform each activity. If you $\qquad$ recall the previous lessons, the methods are just applicable for a specific quadratic equation. For $\qquad$ example, the process of ‚Äúfactoring‚Äù is appropriate only if the quadratic expression is factorable. But $\qquad$ do not worry because there is one process that is applicable for all forms of quadratic equations that $\qquad$ will be tackled in this module. It is all about solving quadratic equations using quadratic formula.

### **V. LESSON CONTENT**

$\qquad$ $\qquad$ We begin our study of quadratic equations with a look at the concepts of simplifying radicals. $\qquad$ Take note that a simplified radical has none of the factors of radicand can be written as powers $\qquad$ $\qquad$ greater than or equal to the index, there are no fractions under the radical sign and no radicals in  $\qquad$the denominator.

$\qquad$ Study how the given radical expressions are simplified.

a.  $$
    \begin{aligned}
    4 + \sqrt{500} &= 4 + \sqrt{(100)(5)}  && \text{Factor out 500 such that one number is the greatest possible perfect square factor.} \\
    & = 4 + 10\sqrt{5} && \text{Simplify the radical part and combine terms, whenever possible.}
    \end{aligned}
    $$

b.  $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{-6-\sqrt{12}}{4} &= \dfrac{-6-\sqrt{(4)(3)}}{4}  && \text{Factor out 12 such that one number is the possible perfect square factor} \\
    & =  \dfrac{-6-2\sqrt{3}}{4}&& \text{Simplify the radical part} \\
    & =  \dfrac{2(-3-\sqrt{3})}{4}&& \text{Factor out the common monomial factor of the numerator, then simplify} \\
    & =  \dfrac{-3-\sqrt{3}}{2}
    \end{aligned}
    $$

#### **WHAT‚ÄôS NEW**

$\qquad$ **Please Throw the Ball!**

$\qquad$ A certain group of boys play a ball outside Erick‚Äôs house when one of them accidentally kicked it $\qquad$ hard and went up to Erick‚Äôs roof. They requested him to get the ball and throw it back to them. $\qquad$ $\qquad$ Without hesitation, Erick helped them and threw the ball from the roof onto the ground 9.14m $\qquad$ $\qquad$ below. He tossed the ball with an initial downward velocity of 3.05m per second. With H as the $\qquad$ $\qquad$ height of an object after t seconds, v as the initial velocity, and h as the initial height, the condition $\qquad$ above is given by the equation $H = -16t^2 + vt + h$. What will be the equation to find how long $\qquad$ it takes the ball to hit the ground? Do you think the methods of solving quadratic equation that you $\qquad$ have learned in the previous modules will help you solve the equation you made?

#### **WHAT IS IT**

$\qquad$ The quadratic equation that can be formed from the story model earlier is $$H=-16t^2+3.05t+9.14=0.$$ $\qquad$ Do you think the methods discussed previously can be used to solve for the roots of the obtained $\qquad$ equation? Why? There are quadratic equations that are difficult to solve by extracting the square $\qquad$ roots, factoring or even completing the squares. These quadratic equations need a formula that will $\qquad$ help you in solving for their roots.

#### **WHAT IS IN**

$\qquad$ The quadratic formula, $x=\dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}$, is derived from standard form of quadratic equation, $ax^2+bx+c=0$ by applying the method of completing the square shown below.

| Steps                                                                                                              | Illustrative                                                                                                                                    |
|------------------------------------|------------------------------------|
| 1. Place the constant term on the right side of the equation. All the terms with unknowns are on the left side.   | $$ax^2+bx+c=0 \to ax^2+bx=-c$$                                                                                                                  |
| 2. Divide each term of the equation with the numerical coefficient of x\^2 if necessary.                          | $$\dfrac{ax^2+bx}{a}=\dfrac{-c}{a} \to x^2+\frac{bx}{a}=\dfrac{-c}{a}$$                                                                         |
| 3. Get the numerical coefficient of x, divide it by 2 and square it. Add the result to both sides of the equation | $$\dfrac{1}{2} \left( \dfrac{b}{2a} \right) = \dfrac{b}{2a} \to \left( \dfrac{b}{2a} \right)^2 = \dfrac{b^2}{4a^2}$$                            |
| 4. Factor the perfect square trinomial.                                                                           | $$ x^2 + \dfrac{bx}{a} + \dfrac{b^2}{4a^2} = \dfrac{-c}{a} + \dfrac{b^2}{4a^2} \to \left( x + \dfrac{b}{2a} \right)^2 = \dfrac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}$$ |
| 5. Extract the square root from both sides. Two values will be obtained for the right side of the equation.       | $$ x+\dfrac{b}{2a} = \pm \sqrt {\dfrac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}} \to x+\dfrac{b}{2a} = \pm \dfrac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} $$                                  |
| 6. Solve for x by transposing $\dfrac{b}{2a}$ on the right of the equation                                        | $$ x = \pm \dfrac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} -\dfrac{b}{2a}$$                                                                                          |
| 7. Combine like terms on the right side.                                                                          | $$ x = \dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} $$                                                                                                     |

#### **Example**

Solve for the real roots of each equation using quadratic formula

1.  $x^2-2x-19=0$

$\qquad$ **Solution:**

$\qquad$ $a=1$ $b=-2$ $c=-19$

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & = \dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} && \text{Quadratic Formula} \\
x&= \dfrac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^2-4(1)(-19)}}{2(1)} && \text{Substitute the values of a, b and c} \\
x&= \dfrac{2 \pm \sqrt{4+76}}{2} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= \dfrac{2 \pm \sqrt{80}}{2} && \text{Evaluate the square root, if possible} \\
x&= \dfrac{2 \pm 4\sqrt{5}}{2} \\
x&= \dfrac{2( 1 \pm 2\sqrt{5})}{2} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= 1 \pm 2\sqrt{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

2.  $2x^2+6x=-3$

$\qquad$ **Solution:**

$\qquad$ When $2x^2+6x=-3$ is changed to standard form, we have $2x^2+6x+3=0$. The value of $a=2$, $\qquad$ $b=6$, and $c=3$

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & = \dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} && \text{Quadratic Formula} \\
x&= \dfrac{-6 \pm \sqrt{(6)^2-4(2)(3)}}{2(2)} && \text{Substitute the values of a, b and c} \\
x&= \dfrac{-6 \pm \sqrt{36-24}}{4} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= \dfrac{-6 \pm \sqrt{12}}{4} && \text{Evaluate the square root, if possible} \\
x&= \dfrac{-6 \pm 4\sqrt{(4)(3)}}{2} \\
x&= \dfrac{-6\pm 2\sqrt{3})}{2} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3 \pm \sqrt{3}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\qquad$ The roots are $\dfrac{-3 \pm \sqrt{3}}{2}$

3.$2x^2+3x-27=0$

$\qquad$ **Solution:**

$\qquad$ $a=2$, $b=3$, and $c=-27$

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & = \dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} && \text{Quadratic Formula} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3 \pm \sqrt{(3)^2-4(2)(-27)}}{2(2)} && \text{Substitute the values of a, b and c} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9-(-26)}}{4} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3 \pm \sqrt{225}}{4} && \text{Evaluate the square root, if possible} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3 \pm 15}{4} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3 + 15}{4} \qquad x=\dfrac{-3 -15}{4} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= \dfrac{12}{4} \qquad x=\dfrac{-18}{4} \\
x&= 3 \qquad x=\dfrac{-9}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

4.  $2x^2+9x=-10$

$\qquad$ **Solution**

$\qquad$ When $2x^2+9x=-10$ is changed to standard form, we have $2x^2+9x+10=0$. The value of $\qquad$ $a=2$, $b=9$, and $c=10$

$$
\begin{aligned}
x& = \dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} && \text{Quadratic Formula} \\
x&= \dfrac{-9 \pm \sqrt{(9)^2-4(2)(10)}}{2(2)} && \text{Substitute the values of a, b and c} \\
x&= \dfrac{-9 \pm \sqrt{81-80}}{4} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= \dfrac{-9 \pm \sqrt{1}}{4} && \text{Evaluate the square root, if possible} \\
x&= \dfrac{-9 \pm 1}{4} \\
x&= \dfrac{-9+1}{4}, \qquad x=\dfrac{-9-1}{4} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= \dfrac{-8}{4}, \qquad x=\dfrac{-10}{4} \\
x&= -2, \qquad x=\dfrac{-5}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

5.  $2x^2-3x+4=0$

$\qquad$ **Solution:**

$\qquad$ $a=2$, $b=-3$, and $c=4$

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & = \dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} && \text{Quadratic Formula} \\
x&= \dfrac{-(-3) \pm \sqrt{(-3)^2-4(2)(4)}}{2(2)} && \text{Substitute the values of a, b and c} \\
x&= \dfrac{3 \pm \sqrt{-23}}{4} && \text{Simplify}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\qquad$ Notice that the radicand is negative. It indicates that the roots are non-real.

B. Analyze and Solve.

1.  Erick throws the ball from the roof onto the ground 9.14m below. He tosses the ball with an initial downward velocity of 3.05 m per second. With H as the height of an object after t seconds, v as the initial velocity, and h as the initial height, the condition above is given by the equation $ùêª = ‚àí16ùë°^2 + ùë£ùë° + ‚Ñé$, how long does it take for the ball to hit the ground?

$\qquad$ **Solution:**

$\qquad$ This is the story model we had earlier. Given the equation $ùêª = ‚àí16ùë°^2 + ùë£ùë° + ‚Ñé$, if the ball hits the $\qquad$ ground then the height, H, is zero. Thus, the quadratic equation is $‚àí16ùë°^2 + 3.05ùë° + 9.14 = 0$. $\qquad$ $\qquad$ Solving for the time it takes the ball to hit the ground,

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & = \dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} && \text{Quadratic Formula} \\
x&= \dfrac{-(3.05) \pm \sqrt{(3.05)^2-4(-16)(9.14)}}{2(-16)} && \text{Substitute the values of a, b and c} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3.05 \pm \sqrt{9.3025+584.96}}{2(-16)} && \text{Simplify} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3.05 \pm \sqrt{594.2625}}{-32} && \text{Evaluate the square root, if possible} \\
x&= \dfrac{-3.05 \pm 24.38}{-32} \\
x&= -0.67, \qquad x= 0.86
\end{aligned}
$$

$\qquad$ Since $-0.67$ seconds is not possible, thus the will hit the ground in $0.86$ seconds.
